metadata.Title: CVE-2017-9217 on Ubuntu 14.04 ESM (trusty) - low.
metadata.Description:
systemd-resolved through 233 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (daemon crash) via a crafted DNS response with an empty question section.

Update Instructions:

Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2017-9217` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
by updating your system to the following package versions:

gir1.2-gudev-1.0 - 204-5ubuntu20.24
libgudev-1.0-0 - 204-5ubuntu20.24
No subscription required

libpam-systemd - 204-5ubuntu20.24
libsystemd-daemon0 - 204-5ubuntu20.24
libsystemd-id128-0 - 204-5ubuntu20.24
libsystemd-journal0 - 204-5ubuntu20.24
libsystemd-login0 - 204-5ubuntu20.24
libudev1 - 204-5ubuntu20.24
python-systemd - 204-5ubuntu20.24
systemd - 204-5ubuntu20.24
systemd-services - 204-5ubuntu20.24
udev - 204-5ubuntu20.24
No subscription required

notes.Note: tyhicks> I believe that this was introduced in v223 by https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/29815b6c608b836cada5e349d06a96b63eaa65f3 Lennart pointed out in the pull request that systemd-resolved is respawned after crashing. Therefore, I've rated this as a low priority. systemd-resolved became the default DNS resolver in Zesty and it is enabled in Yakkety systemd-resolved is not used by default in Xenial. It is spawned if a user execs the systemd-resolve utility but that shouldn't impact the system.

criterions.comment: systemd package in trusty, is related to the CVE in some way and has been fixed (note: '204-5ubuntu20.24').
